questions.question: Which of the following form the third-order neurons in the visual pathway?
questions.explanation: Ganglion cells are the third-order neurons in the visual pathway.

questions.question: A 41-year-old woman with a known pituitary microadenoma presented with sudden-onsetvisual disturbances, headache, and hypotension during the second trimester ofWhat is the visual field defect this patient is most likely to experience?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pituitary apoplexy in pregnancy This acute onset eventis almost always associated with compression at the level of optic chiasma causing heteronymoushemianopia (bitemporal hemianopia).Pituitary apoplexy results from hemorrhagic infarction of a pre-existing pituitary adenoma orwithin a physiologically enlarged gland, which is well documented in pregnancy.The nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma. Slow-growing microadenomascompress lower nasal optic fibers causing superior temporal quadrantanopia initially, beforeprogressing to bitemporal hemianopia. However, an abrupt infarction or hemorrhage of apre-existing pituitary adenoma will lead to rapid progression of the visual defect.Heteronymous hemianopia is the loss of half of the visual field on different sides in both eyes. It isseparated into two categories:• Binasal hemianopia - the loss of the fields surrounding the nose•Bitemporal hemianopia - the loss of the fields closest to the temples.Common causes of bitemporal hemianopia due to central chiasmal lesions are as follows:•Suprasellar aneurysms• Tumors of the pituitary gland497•Craniopharyngioma• Suprasellar meningioma•Glioma of the third ventricleOther visual defects according to the site of the lesion are as follows:Visual Pathway Lesions – Optic NerveHead to Optic TractOptic Nerve Head (Unilateral)Big blind spotLeftTemporalNanalOptic Nerve (Unilateral)RightTunnel VisionVisualOptiochiasm15LateralgenioutatenucleuANVisual cortex area 170Inner Optic Nerve (Unilateral)Central ScotomaWhole Optic Nerve (Unilateral)Unilateral BlindnessProximal part of Optic NerveJunctionalScotomaCentral Chiasma (Bilateral)Bitemporal Hemianopia.Carliest Pituitary AdenomaBilateral TemporalSuperior QuadrantanopiaEarliest CraniopharyngiomaGDFilateral TemporalInferior QuadrantanopinMARROWLateral Chiasma (Bilateral)Dinasal HemianopiaOptic Tract (Dilateral)Bilateral HomonymousHemianopla

questions.question: Which of the following cannot be tested with monocular visual field testing using a pin with ared pinhead?
questions.explanation: Central scotoma, paracentral scotoma and temporal field defects can be tested by monocularvisual field testing with a red-headed neurological pin.A patient who has central scotoma will either not see the pinhead in the centre of the field orperceive it black. This can be defined by moving the pin outwards in four different directions untilthe patient sees the pinhead as being red.Placing the pin in each of the quadrants close to the centre and checking if the patient sees the redpinhead can detect a paracentral scotoma. This can also detect temporal field defects.

questions.question: A lesion in which of the following structures is most likely to result in congruoushomonymous hemianopia?489
questions.explanation: Congruous homonymous hemianopia is most suggestive of a lesion in the occipital cortex.Homonymous hemianopia involves vision loss on the same side of the visual field in both eyes.This type of visual field loss is suggestive of a lesion posterior to the optic chiasma in the visualpathway.Complete homonymous hemianopia involves the complete visual hemifields of both eyes and canoccur with any large enough lesion posterior to the optic chiasma. Visual field examination alonecannot further localize the lesion in such cases.498Incomplete homonymous hemianopia is due to smaller lesions in the visual pathway posterior tothe optic chiasm. They are further divided into congruous and incongruous depending on theextent to which the defects in the two half fields match each other exactly.Because of a relative disorder among axon bundles in the immediate post-chiasmal region,diseases in this location produce rather incongruent lesions.More posteriorly, the axon bundles of the corresponding areas of the two hemifields are moreclosely aligned and hence, lesions of the occipital cortex produce congruous homonymoushemianopia while incongruous homonymous hemianopia is more likely seen with optic tractlesions.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman presented with a persistent headache for the past few months. Onevaluation, her vision on Snellen's chart was 6/6 in both eyes. The fundus also appears to benormal. Visual field charting shows a bitemporal visual field defect. Site of the lesion is
questions.explanation: The site of the lesion is optic chiasma. Lesions at the chiasma characteristicallyproduce bitemporal field defects due to the decussation of nasal fibres.In retrochiasmal lesions, homonymous hemianopia is seen. Further, in cortical lesions, macular(central) vision is spared.

questions.question: A young patient with visual disturbances was found to have a brain tumour. He was referredto ophthalmology for a complete visual field assessment before planning his resection.Humprey analyzer revealed the following plot. What is the most likely site of the lesion?C
questions.explanation: The visual field defect shown is the typical "pie in the sky" defect or superior quadrantichemianopia. They are produced when the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporallobe (Meyer's loop) are involved."Pie in the floor" defects refer to inferior quadrantic hemianopia. It is seen in the involvement ofthe superior fibers of optic radiations in the parietal lobe (Baum's loop).

questions.question: A 72-year-old lady was brought by her son with bilateral loss of vision for 3 days, associatedwith slurred speech. It was preceded by an occipital headache. Despite her obvious blindness,illustrated by her walking into objects, the patient denied visual loss. MRI revealed bilateraloccipital infarcts. Which of the following statement is true regarding the given condition?

options.A: Direct and consensual reflexes are absent in both eyes.
options.B: Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes.
options.C: Direct reflex is present but consensual reflex is absent.
options.D: Consensual reflex is present but direct reflex is absent.

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cortical blindness with visual anosognosia (Antonsyndrome). Since anterior visual pathways are not affected in cortical blindness, direct andconsensual light reflexes are preserved.Cortical blindness is usually associated with bilateral occipital infarcts where it is supplied by theposterior cerebral arteries and these infarcts usually involve both the primary visual cortex andvisual association area. It is secondary to damage to the visual pathways posterior to the lateralgeniculate nuclei; anterior visual pathways are intact. Visual field defects can vary depending onthe extent and location of the infarct.Direct and consensual reflexes are present in both eyes in cortical blindness as pupillary lightreflex fibers exit the visual pathway at the level of the superior colliculus. They exit the optic tractbefore the lateral geniculate body (LGB) to reach the center for pupillary light reflex- pretectalnucleus at the midbrain.Note: Anton syndrome is visual anosognosia (denial of loss of vision) associated withconfabulation (defined as the emergence of memories of events and experiences which never tookplace) in the setting of obvious visual loss and cortical blindness.

questions.question: A neurology resident is demonstrating spinal reflexes in a comatose patient. When he pinchesthe skin over the side of the patient's neck, there is a rapid dilatation of the ipsilateral pupil.Which of the following forms the efferent limb of this reflex?
questions.explanation: The given scenario describes cilio-spinal reflex. Sympathetic fibers of cervical ganglion form theefferent limb of this reflex.Cilio-spinal reflex:• Afferent inputs of this reflex are carried by the trigeminal nerve or cervical pain fibers (lateralspinothalamic tract).500• It synapses at the ciliospinal center of Budge, located at C8 to T2 in the intermediolateral (IML)horn of the gray matter of the spinal cord.••The efferent branch of the reflex consists of:Preganglionic sympathetic fibers from the upper thoracic and lower cervical spinal cordwhich goes to the cervical sympathetic chain and its three ganglia.• The postganglionic sympathetic fibers pass on the surface of the internal carotid artery and jointhe ophthalmic nerve at the cavernous sinus. Here, it passes through the nasociliary nerve toreach the ciliary body and innervates the dilator pupillae muscles, causing dilatation of the pupil.This reflex is absent in Horner's syndrome and in lesions involving the cervical sympathetic fibersand it is enhanced in patients with cluster headache and barbiturate-induced coma.

questions.question: 491Which of the following is not part of the pupillary light reflex pathway?
questions.explanation: The lateral geniculate body is not a part of the pupillary reflex pathway. It is part of theaccommodation reflex and the visual pathway.Pupillary light reflex pathway:• First neurons (sensory) connects each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at thelevel of the superior colliculi.• Second neurons (internuncial) connects each pretectal nucleus to both Edinger-Westphal nuclei.•Third neurons (preganglionic motor) connects the Edinger-Westphal nucleus to the ciliaryganglion.• Fourth neurons (postganglionic motor) leaves the ciliary ganglion and passes in the short ciliarynerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae.Image: Pupillary reflex pathwaysAccommodation and Light reflex-RetinaCiliaryganglionSphincterpupillae-RetinaOpticnerveOpticOculomotornervesLateralgeniculatebodyOpticradiationPretectalolivarynucleusStriatearea ofvisualcortexAccommodation reflexchiasm Ciliary-ganglionEdinger-WestphalnucleusOpticnérveOpticchiasmOculomotornervesLateralgeniculatebodyPretectalolivarynucleusOMARROW501Edinger-WestphalnucleusPupillary light reflex

questions.question: A patient presented with diplopia to the casualty. On examination, the left pupil was dilated.Both direct and consensual light reflexes were lost in the affected eye. What is the mostprobable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical situation suggests that the patient has III nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy.Absence of contraction of the pupil in both direct and consensual reflex suggests a lesion in theefferent pathway of the affected eye. This is III nerve/oculomotor palsy.Light reflex consists of direct and consensual reflexes.When light is shone in an eye,• Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.• Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflexFor the light reflex,• Afferent nerve fiber is the II cranial nerve (optic nerve).• Efferent nerve fiber is the III cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve)-BilaterallyIn II nerve palsy, there will be a loss of direct reflex in the affected eye and loss of consensual lightreflex in the opposite eye.

questions.question: A male patient came with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse around 20 years ago.Now, he complains of neurological symptoms and visual disturbances. Which of the followingwill be seen on exposure of his pupils to light?

options.A: Pupils react but do not accommodate.
options.B: Pupils accommodate but do not react.

questions.explanation: The patient most likely has acquired syphilis due to unprotected sex and hasdeveloped neurological and visual disturbances secondarily as a complication of neurosyphilis.Argyll-Robertson pupils (ARP) are seen associated with neurosyphilis where the pupilsaccommodate but do not react to light.Argyll Robertson pupil is attributed to a dorsal midbrain lesion of neurosyphilis that affects thepupillary light pathway but spares the more ventrally placed pupillary near reflexpathway(Accomdation pathway), thereby causing a light-near dissociation.Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP) include:• Bilateral small, irregular pupils in dim light• Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)- The eye accomdates by constricting the pupil for a neartarget.⚫ Light Reflex absent: pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.• Cocaine eye drops(mydriatics) induced mydriasis.Other clinical features in neurosyphilis:Fleeting and repetitive lancinating pains, primarily in the legs• acute abdominal pain with vomiting(visceral crisis)• Tabes dorsalis with Ataxia and gait disturbances due to loss of position sense• Loss of reflexes in the legs•• Paresthesias, bladder disturbancesOther causes of light-near dissociation are:502In unilateral eye• Adie pupil• Herpes zoster ophthalmicus• Aberrant regeneration of the third cranial nerveIn bilateral eyes• Neurosyphilis• Type 1 diabetes mellitus•Myotonic dystrophyNote: Adie's pupil more commonly manifests in young women with unilateral large regularpupil(Anisocoria) with absent light reflex and sluggish and tonic accomdation reflex.It is caused by post-ganglionic parasympathetic pupillary supply damage and is usually associatedwith absent knee jerk.Adie's pupil constricts with weak pilocarpine (0.1%) drops, while normal pupil and Argyllrobertson pupil does not.

questions.question: Which of the following would you suspect in a patient who presents with small pupils?
questions.explanation: Pontine hemorrhage is associated with small pupils. The remaining options, namely, carbonmonoxide poisoning, ethylene glycol poisoning, and Holmes-Adie pupil, cause dilation of thepupils.

questions.question: A 67-year-old woman finally decides to get glasses, about thirty years after she actuallyneeded them, and goes to an optometrist for an eyeglass prescription. Her eye examinationreveals some unexpected findings. The pupils were small. When a pen-light is shone on to hereyes,neither pupil contracts. However, when the optometrist brings his fingers towards herface, both pupils constrict dramatically. What is the given condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical situation of bilateral small irregular pupils with light-near dissociation suggestsa diagnosis of Argyll Robertson pupil.Features of Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP):• Accommodation Reflex Present (ARP)•• Light Reflex absent• Constricted pupil• An example of light near dissocation.• Seen in neurosyphilisOption A: Anisocoria is when the pupils are not of the same size.Option B: Adie's tonic pupil•Light reflex absent or sluggish.• Near reflex: Slow and tonic• Pupil is larger503• Constricts with weak pilocarpine.Option C: Ophthalmoplegia interna• Dilated paralyzed pupil• Does not respond to light or accommodation

questions.question: Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is due to a lesion in the
questions.explanation: Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is due to a lesion in the optic tract.The optic tracts contain both visual and pupillomotor fibers.The visual fibers terminate in the lateral geniculate body, but the pupillary fibers leave the optictract anterior to the lateral geniculate body, projecting through the brachium of the superiorcolliculus to terminate in the pretectal nuclei.An optic tract lesion may, therefore, give rise to an afferent pupillary conduction defect.Characteristically, the pupillary light reflex will be normal when the unaffected hemiretina isstimulated and absent, when the involved hemiretina is stimulated (i.e., light is shone from thehemianopic side).
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Visual Pathway and Pupillary Reflexes

questions.question: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient withprimary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.explanation: Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nervedamage. Marcus Gunn pupil also known as relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is the earliestsign of optic nerve disease as seen in optic nerve neuritis or primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).RAPD is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex inone eye.It is diagnosed by the swinging flashlight test where the flashlight is swung to and fro, and thepupillary response is observed. Normally, both pupils constrict when any one eye is stimulated(due to direct and consensual light reflex). In the presence of RAPD, bothpupils will abnormally dilate when the affected eye is stimulated. This paradoxical response of thepupil to light is called Marcus Gunn pupil.Causes of RAPD:• Optic nerve lesions (e.g.All types of optic neuritis, glaucoma)•Optic tract lesions (e.g., infarction)• Severe retinal disease (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion, extensive retinal detachment)•Maculopathy (macular degeneration)Other options:Option B: Adie tonic pupil is a unilateral dilated pupil with light-near dissociation due topostganglionic parasympathetic pupillomotor nerve supply damage. In these patients the lightreflex is absent and the accomdation (near) reflex is sluggish. It is commonly seen in young504females and is associated with absent knee jerk.Option C: Argyll Robertson pupils are bilateral small pupils with light-near dissociation. It iscommonly seen in patients with neurosyphilis. In these patients the pupillary reflex is absent butthe accommodation reflex is present (ARP).Option D: Hutchinson's pupil is a clinical sign where the pupil on the side of an intracranial masslesion is dilated and unreactive to light, due to compression of the oculomotor nerve on that side.

questions.question: The casualty intern noticed that a patient had unequal pupils. The anisocoria was greaterunder light. Which of the following drugs would be helpful in quickly differentiating betweenthe potential causes?
questions.explanation: Anisocoria greater in the light indicates the large pupil to be abnormal due to poor pupillarycontraction from a parasympathetic abnormality. Among the given options, 1% pilocarpine and0.1% pilocarpine can be used to differentiate fixed dilated pupil.Mydriasis due to neurologic origin (3rd nerve palsy) responds readily to 1% pilocarpine, whereasthere will be no response if the dilation is due to anticholinergic causes. Pupillary constrictionto 0.1% pilocarpine diagnoses Adie's pupil (due to denervation hypersensitivity). Application of0.1% pilocarpine shows no response in other conditions or in the normal eye.Example: A person presenting with dilated pupil following accidental application or inadvertentrubbing of atropine or antimuscarinic alkaloids from wild plants into the eye will not constrict inresponse to topical application of 1% Pilocarpine. But the patient showing dilation due to 3rdnerve palsy shows pupillary constriction in response to pupillary instillation of 1% pilocarpine.Note: Cocaine and phenylephrine are used in anisocoria that is greater in the dark to diagnoseHorner's syndrome. In these patients, the small pupil fails to dilate even after the instillation ofcocaine.

questions.question: A 55-year-old lady with advanced spondylosis underwent cervical vertebral fusion surgery. Inthe post-operative room, the resident noted that her pupils were unequal. Which of thefollowing features would rule out the possibility of Horner's syndrome in this patient?
questions.explanation: Horner's syndrome causes all the following except mydriasis. It causes miosis.Horner's syndrome (oculosympathetic palsy)The majority of the cases are unilateral.Causes of bilateral involvement include cervical spine injuries and autonomic diabeticneuropathy.Painful Horner syndrome, especially of acute onset, should raise the possibility of carotiddissection.Clinical features• Mild ptosis (usually 1-2 mm) as a result of weakness of Müller muscle•Anisocoria is accentuated in dim light•Pupillary constriction to light and near stimuli is normal.⚫ Hypochromic heterochromia (lighter color iris on affected side); in congenital cases.•505• Mild ptosis (Mullers muscle is affected)• Reduced ipsilateral sweating (only if the lesion is below the superior cervical ganglion)Pharmacological tests• Hydroxyamphetamine and adrenaline may be used to differentiate a preganglionic from apostganglionic lesion.•Phenylepherine (1%)• Result: In an established (10 days) postganglionic lesion, the Horner pupil will dilate and ptosismay be temporarily relieved. A central or preganglionic Horner pupil and a normal pupil will notdilate or will dilate minimally.• Explanation: In postganglionic Horner's syndrome, the dilator pupillae muscle developsdenervation hypersensitivity to adrenergic neurotransmitters due to its dysfunctional local motornerve.•• Apraclonidine (0.5% or 1.0%)• Result: A Horner pupil will dilate, but a normal pupil is essentially unaffected.•Explanation: Alpha-1 receptors are upregulated in the denervated dilator pupillae.• Cocaine (4%) is instilled into both eyes••Result: The normal pupil will dilate, but the Horner pupil will not.• Explanation: Cocaine blocks the re-uptake of noradrenaline secreted at the postganglionic nerveending, which accumulates and causes dilatation of a normal pupil. In Horner's syndrome, thereis no noradrenaline being secreted, so cocaine has no effect.

questions.question: Where is the cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil?
questions.explanation: The cell body of the second-order neuron in the sympathetic pathway for the pupil lies at theciliospinal center of Budge (C8–T1).The sympathetic pathway to the iris muscles consists of a chain of three neurons:• The first neuron arises from the hypothalamus along the brain stem to synapse inthe intermediolateral column of the spinal cord-the ciliospinal center of Budge (C8-T1).• From here (C8-T1), the second-order neuron arises. This joins the cervical sympathetic chain andsynapses at the superior cervical ganglion.• The third-order neuron arises from the superior cervical ganglion and travels through the•cavernous sinus along with the internal carotid artery.Sympathetic fibers join the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve and pass through theciliary ganglion to the nasociliary and short ciliary nerves.506Oculosympathetic pathwayCiliary nervesOphthalmic division oftrigeminal nerveHypothalamusBlocking of:- Sweat glands offorehead(anhydrosis)• Smooth muscle ofeyelid (ptosis)- Dilator pupillae(miosis)- Sweat glands of face(anhydrosis)MExternal carotid arteryThird-order lesion.Third-order neuronSuperior cervical ganglionMiddle cervical ganglion.Second-order neuronSecond-order lesionSympathetic chainMARROWInternalcarotidarteryFirst-orderneuronFirst-orderlesionT₁T₂SpinalcordTa

questions.question: A simultaneous lesion in both sympathetic and parasympathetic supply of the eye leads towhich of the following?

options.A: Mydriatic pupil that reacts to light
options.B: Constricted pupil that reacts to light
options.C: Mid-sized pupil that doesn't react to light
options.D: Mid-sized pupil that reacts to light

questions.explanation: Simultaneous lesion in both sympathetic and parasympathetic supply of the eye leads to mid-sizedpupil that doesn't react to light.Pupillary dilation is achieved by sympathetic innervation of dilator pupillae. Therefore, any lesionof the sympathetic supply of the pupil leads to constricted pupil.Pupillary constriction is a parasympathetic function. Lesions in this pathway leads to dilated pupiland failure to constrict.A mid-sized unreactive pupil due to a lesion of both parasympathetic and sympathetic supplies isseen in aneurysms of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus.

questions.question: 494During the neurological examination of a patient, on shining light in his left eye, the left pupildoes not constrict but the right pupil does. On shining light in his right eye, the right pupilconstricts and left doesn't. The defect is in:
questions.explanation: The above scenario is suggestive of left eye efferent (oculomotor nerve) defect.The loss of pupillary light reflex (both direct and consensual) in the left eye associated with apreserved direct pupillary response in the right eye is characteristic of an efferent pupillary defect.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common feature of third nerve palsy, in a case oflong-standing, uncontrolled diabetes?
questions.explanation: The most common feature seen in diabetic oculomotor palsy among the given options is ptosis.In the anatomical arrangement of the nerve fibers of the 3rd cranial nerve, the fibers controllingthe pupillary reflex are present superficially and are thus spared from diabetic ischemia-inducedinjury which starts from the central nerve fibres. Thus, pupil sparing is commonly seen in diabeticpatients.507The etiology of diabetic neuropathy is hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronalischemic change due to microvascular angiopathy.Involvement of the third cranial nerve is most common and it often presents with early features ofptosis and diplopia with pupil sparing.The involvement of levator palpebrae superioris muscle of the eyelid manifests as ptosis and theinvolvement of extraocular muscles such as medial rectus, inferior rectus and inferior obliquepresents as opthalmoplegia with diplopia. All the muscles mentioned above are supplied by theOcculomotor nerve.Note: Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery is an important cause of isolated thirdnerve palsy with involvement of the pupil. This is because the aneurysm impinges on thesuperficial pupil nerve fibres of the 3rd cranial nerve.

questions.question: A 60-year-old man was brought to the OPD by his daughter with complaints of drooping ofhis left eyelid and double vision. The pupillary examination was normal. What is the likelycause?
questions.explanation: Ptosis and double vision with no other features suggest an acquired, isolated 3rd nerve palsy withpupillary sparing. This is seen in ischemic conditions such as diabetes.The vasoneurium supplies the nerve from outside to inside. As the somatic fibres are located inthe inner part of the nerve, these fibres are affected more in the setting of ischemia. Theparasympathetic pupillary fibres which run on the outside can remain unaffected (resulting inpupillary sparing). In compressive lesions, the parasympathetic fibres are affected before anydisruption of the motor fibres. So pupillary sparing is not seen.Isolated 3rd nerve palsyCauses• Microvascular disease associated with systemic risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes isthe most common cause of third nerve palsy.• Aneurysm of the posterior communicating artery at its junction with the internal carotid, bothdirect and secondary to subdural hematoma with uncal herniation.••Episodic migraine, compression, ischemia, and alterations in intracranial pressureMiscellaneous- tumour and inflammatory diseases such as syphilis, Lyme disease, andsarcoidosis; giant cell arteritis; and vasculitis associated with collagen vascular disorders.Signs• Profound ptosis due to the weakness of the levator muscle.• Abduction and depression in the primary position ("down and out")• Normal abduction as the lateral rectus is intact• Limited adduction due to medial rectus weakness• Limited elevation due to the weakness of the superior rectus and inferior oblique508
questions.chapter_heading: Disorders of Visual Pathway and Pupillary Reflexes

questions.question: The patient presented with the following appearance when asked to look straight. What is theprobable diagnosis?495
questions.explanation: The above image shows adduction of the right eye due to paralysis of the right lateral rectus,indicating right abducens (6th) nerve palsy.The nucleus of the sixth (abducens or abducent) nerve lies at the mid-level of the pons.Nuclear lesion: A nuclear sixth nerve lesion also causes the failure of horizontal gaze towards theside of the damage due to the involvement of the adjacent horizontal gaze center (paramedianpontine reticular formation).Foville (inferior medial pontine) syndrome is most frequently caused by vascular disease ortumors involving the dorsal pons. It is characterized by the following:•Ipsilateral involvement of the fifth to eighth cranial nerves•Central sympathetic fibers (Horner syndrome)• Horizontal gaze palsyMillard-Gubler (ventral pontine) syndrome involves the fasciculus as it passes through thepyramidal tract. As well as ipsilateral sixth nerve palsy, there is contralateral hemiplegia and oftenan ipsilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve palsy.Clinical features:•Esotropia in the primary position due to relatively unopposed action of the medial rectus•Limitation of abduction on the side of the lesion•Normal adduction of the affected eye• A compensatory face turn is towards the side of the paralyzed muscle in unilateral palsy509
